subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] dictionary, script not working
msgSnippet: Thanks for bringing this dictionary to our attention, Chuck. I see that their phoneme list does not include QS #20, and it s ambiguous about the distinction
messageBody:
Thanks for bringing this dictionary to our attention, Chuck.

I see that their phoneme list does not include QS #20, and it's ambiguous about the distinction between QS #32 and QS #34. (I equate their 'AO' with QS #33, even though I can't tell the difference myself.)

In fact, the reason I started looking for a dictionary was to look for some pattern that I could follow in guessing which of the lettters #32, #33, and #34 is most appropriate in different words. Since I'm from Western North America, I cannot tell them apart.

Ted


On 10/17/07, Chuck Peck <chuck.peck@...> wrote:

Further details,
 
Check out the "The Carnegie Mellon Pronouncing Dictionary [cmudict.0.6] " It use to be at http://www.speech.cs.cmu.edu/cgi-bin/cmudict
 
 
It's got a list of words and their phonitic symbols.
CAIRO  K AY1 R OW0
CAIRO'S  K AY1 R OW0 Z
CAISON  K EY1 Z AH0 N
CAISSE  K EY1 S
CAISSIE  K EY1 S IY0
CAITLIN  K EY1 T L IH2 N
CAITO  K EY1 T OW0
CAJOLE  K AH0 JH OW1 L
CAJOLED  K AH0 JH OW1 L D
CAJOLING  K AH0 JH OW1 L IH0 NG
CAJUN  K EY1 JH AH0 N
CAJUNS  K EY1 JH AH0 N Z
CAKE  K EY1 K
 
On the site is a legand for the above symbols. A simple search and replace is all you need to do.
 
 
Good luck!
 
Chuck Peck
 

From: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com [mailto:Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Paul Tremblay
Sent: Tuesday, October 16, 2007 8:54 PM
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] dictionary, script not working

Chuck Peck wrote:
>
>
> Hello All,
>
> I'm Chuck Peck, I'm the one who built the dictionary. I built it using a
> plain text phonetic dictionary. Check out http://wordnet.princeton.edu/
>
> The dictionary was built using a series of search and replace command,
> looking for the phonetic symbol and replacing it with the appropriate
> roman character for the QS font. The results were imported into a MS
> Access database. A report was generated to create most of the final
> dictionary content.
>
> I hope that helps.
> Chuck Peck
>

Yes, that helps quite a bit. Can you give me any tips on how to read the
database? I am good with python and with regular expressions, so I could
use this database in an automatic conversion tool.

Paul
